questions.question_text: Which TWO statements are TRUE about restoring a volume from a block volume backup in the Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) Block Volume service? (Choose two.)

choices.C: You can only restore a volume to the same availability domain in which the original block volume resides.
choices.B: You can restore only one volume from a manual block volume backup.
choices.D: You can restore a block volume backup to a larger volume size.
choices.E: You can restore a volume to any availability domain within the same region where the backup is stored.
choices.A: You can restore a volume from any full volume backup but not from an incremental backup.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
confirmed via documentation B

Selected Answer: A
I agree with A. It will no longer send traffic to it.

questions.question_text: A customer's webserver runs a complicated application on three Baremetal instances that serve as backends on a backend set for an OCI public Load Balancer. If one of the Baremetal instances fails, what will the OCI Load Balancer do?

choices.A: It will no longer send traffic to it.
choices.E: It will launch an API call.
choices.C: It will fix the failing Baremetal instance.
choices.B: It will delete the failing Baremetal instance.
choices.D: It will send an SOS notification.

questions.question_text: Company XYZ is spending $300,000.00 USD per month in egress fees for 7 Petabytes that they consume for Outbound Data Transfer in North America with their current cloud provider. The company is seeking to lower that expense considerably without reducing consumption. You propose migration to OCI because the Gigabyte Outbound Data Transfer in North America costs just $0.0085 USD per month. With OCI, how much will they spend per month for 7 Petabytes of Outbound Data Transfer? (1 Petabyte = 1000 Terabytes)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
confirmed via documentation C

Selected Answer: D
0.0085*1000*1000*7=59500

inbound is free.
outbound is not free,BUT first 10TB is free.

Selected Answer: B
All User login information comes under audit trail, so answer is B.

Selected Answer: B
To quickly identify the details of all users who were active in the last six hours along with any REST API calls that were executed in Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI), you would typically use the OCI Audit service.

B. Audit:

The Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) Audit service allows you to track and monitor user activity within your OCI tenancy. It records various actions taken by users, including API calls, and provides a searchable and filterable audit trail. You can use the OCI Audit service to query and analyze the activities of users and services within your OCI environment, making it a valuable tool for investigating incidents and identifying configuration errors.

So, the correct answer is B. Audit.

questions.question_text:
You are part of an organization with thousands of users accessing Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI). An unknown user action was executed resulting in configuration errors. You are tasked to quickly identify the details of all users who were active in the last six hours along with any REST API calls that were executed.
Which OCI service would you use?
